raw_text:
Howl helps boost Japan's cinemas
 
 Japan's box office received a 3.8% boost last year, with ticket sales worth 211bn yen (£1.08bn).
 
 The surge was led by animated movie Howl's Moving Castle, which took 20bn yen (£102m) to become the biggest film in Japan in 2004. It is expected to match the 30.7bn yen (£157m) record of Hayao Miyazaki's previous film Spirited Away. Japan Motion Picture Producers figures showed that 170 million cinema admissions were made in Japan in 2004. The Last Samurai, starring Tom Cruise, was the biggest foreign movie hit in Japan last year, taking 13.8bn yen (£70.7m).
 
 It was followed by Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban, Finding Nemo and The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King. The second highest-grossing Japanese film was romantic drama Crying Out Love in the Centre of the World, followed by Be With You and Pocket Monsters Advanced Generation. Japanese films accounted for 37.5% of Japan's box office total last year, with foreign films taking the remaining 62.5%. This represented a 4.5% gain for the proportion of Japanese films in 2004 compared to 2003. The number of Japanese films released rose to 310 in 2004 from 287 the previous year. Sales of movies on DVD and video amounted to 497bn yen (£2.54bn) for the year.
llama3.2:1b: Japan's box office received a 3.8% boost, with ticket sales worth 211bn yen (£1.08bn). Japanese films accounted for 37.5% of total box office, while foreign films took 62.5%. The top-grossing film in 2004 was Howl's Moving Castle, which matched the record set by Spirited Away.
llama3.2:3b: Japan's box office saw a 3.8% boost last year with 211bn yen in ticket sales, boosted by animated movie Howl's Moving Castle taking 20bn yen. Foreign films like The Last Samurai and Harry Potter were also successful, while Japanese films made up 37.5% of the total.
gemma2:2b: Japan's box office saw a 3.8% increase in ticket sales, reaching 211 billion yen (£1.08 billion). The animated film Howl's Moving Castle led the Japanese market with massive success, breaking records and contributing significantly to the surge. Foreign films like "The Last Samurai" also performed well but Japanese cinema holds a strong position in the market, accounting for 37.5% of total sales.  DVD/video sales generated an additional 497 billion yen (£2.54 billion).
qwen2.5:0.5b: Japan's box office received a 3.8% boost last year, with ticket sales worth 211 billion yen (£108 million). It was led by Howl's Moving Castle, which became the biggest film in Japan in 2004 with 20 billion yen (£102 million) and has since become a record for the highest revenue ever recorded. The Last Samurai took second place with 13 billion yen (£70 million), while Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban, Finding Nemo, The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King, Crying Out Love in the Centre of the World, Be With You, and Pocket Monsters Advanced Generation were also among the highest-grossing films. Box office figures show that Japanese cinema accounted for 37.5% of total box office revenue last year, with foreign films contributing 62.5%. The number of movies released rose to 310 in 2004 from 287 the previous year and DVD sales reached a record sum of 497 billion yen (£2.54 billion) for the year.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Howl's Moving Castle boosted Japan's box office by 3.8%, becoming the highest-grossing film in Japan since Spirited Away, contributing to a 4.5% increase in Japanese films' share of domestic cinema admissions compared to the previous year. Other notable releases included The Last Samurai, Harry Potter, Finding Nemo, and Crying Out Love. DVD/Video sales reached 497 billion yen (£2.54bn).
qwen2.5:3b: Howl's Moving Castle boosted Japan's cinemas last year with ticket sales worth 20bn yen, becoming the biggest film in Japan since Spirited Away. This surge led to a 3.8% increase in box office revenue to 211bn yen (£1.08bn). The Last Samurai and Harry Potter movies were other major hits, with Japanese films accounting for 37.5% of total revenue, up from 33% the previous year.
opencoder:1.5b:
Japan's box office received a 3.8% boost last year with ticket sales worth 211 billion yen (1,020 million). The increase was driven by animated movie Howl's Moving Castle which increased its market share to 20 billion yen (102 million), marking the peak in 2004.

It is followed by the film of Hayao Miyazaki's previous Spirited Away, a match for Japan's record-breaking 30.7 billion yen (157 million).

Japan Motion Picture Producers reported that 170 million cinema admissions were made in Japan last year. The film of Tom Cruise was also the biggest foreign film hit with an income of 13.8 billion yen (70.7 million). It accounted for 37.5% of Japan's box office since 2003 compared to 2004.

It also saw a rise in the number of Japanese films released from 287 in 2003 to 310 in 2004, indicating continued growth and potential expansion in the Japanese cinema industry.

Japanese films accounted for 37.5% of Japan's box office total last year, with foreign films taking the remaining 62.5%. <think>
Okay, so I need to summarize this text about Japan's box office performance in 2004. Let me read through it carefully.

First, they mention that Japan's box office saw a 3.8% boost last year, with ticket sales worth 211 billion yen or $1.08 billion. That gives an idea of the overall growth and revenue for Japanese films.

The main driver is Howl's Moving Castle, which made 20 billion yen (around 102 million pounds) and was the biggest film in Japan back then, reaching 30.7 billion yen (about 157 million pounds). This seems like a significant milestone since Hayao Miyazaki's Spirited Away had a record of 30.7 billion yen before.

Then, there are other films they're talking about: Last Samurai took in 13.8 billion yen and was the highest-grossing Japanese movie last year. That shows Japan is growing quickly with foreign films dominating box office revenues.

The data also includes that in 2004, 170 million admissions were made, making Howl's Moving Castle one of the biggest ever. The percentage-wise, Japanese films accounted for 37.5% of the total box office revenue, which is a 4.5% increase compared to 2003.

The number of Japanese films released rose from 287 to 310 in 2004, showing they expanded their repertoire. Movie sales on DVD and video increased by 497 billion yen, contributing to the overall growth.

I need to make sure I capture all these points: the boost, Howl's Moving Castle leading with its success, other top-grossing films, the percentage increase in Japanese films, film release numbers, and DVD/video sales. I should present this concisely without extra information.
</think>

Japan's box office experienced a 3.8% boost last year, totaling 211 billion yen or $1.08 billion. The surge was driven by Howl's Moving Castle, which claimed 20 billion yen and surpassed Hayao Miyazaki's previous film, spirited away, with a record of 30.7 billion yen. Other films like Last Samurai and Harry Potter & the Prisoner of Azkaban also performed well. Japanese films accounted for 37.5% of box office revenue in 2004, up from 2003's 62.5%, with foreign films taking the rest.
tinyllama:1.1b: Japan's box office experienced a surge in sales last year, with Howl's Moving Castle becoming the biggest film ever released in the country by earning 20 billion yen (£102 million) from ticket sales alone. The animation movie also saw a massive boost from foreign films, with Japan Motion Picture Producers figures showing that over 375,000 admissions were made in Japanese cinemas, up from 287 the previous year. Findings Nemo, another successful film, followed closely behind, bringing in 14 billion yen (£9 million) and The Lord of the Rings trilogy rounding out the top three films of the year, selling over 10% more tickets than the previous year's leader. The release of Japanese films also saw an impressive jump in sales, rising from 310 titles to 320 releases for 2004, and foreign films accounting for around 497 billion yen (£2.54 billion) worth of DVD sales and video releases that year.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Howl, a popular animated film from Japan, has played a significant role in boosting Japan's cinema industry by boosting box office revenues with an estimated 211 billion yen (£1.08 billion) worth of ticket sales. Its success is attributed to its unique visual style and powerful storyline that appeals to both young and older audiences, making it a popular choice for both local and foreign filmmakers. This surge in box office revenue has led to Japan Motion Picture Producers figures showing 170 million cinema admissions in 2004, which is an all-time record. Furthermore, the film was also the second highest-grossing Japanese film with a total revenue of $70.7 million (£35.6 million). This surge in popularity for Howl has led to increased investment and collaboration between Japan's animation industry and international studios, resulting in an increase of foreign films being accepted by the Japanese market.
